awd_abstract_narration:
We will fabricate and characterize a self-powered biosensing microsystem that simultaneously generates bioelectricity and monitors glucose. This will be accomplished by using inertial power scavenging design by converting interstitial glucose into energy through the coupling of enzymes and three-dimensional nanowire arrays to potentially power ultra-low power implantable glucose monitors. 

Intellectual Merit: Continuous, self-powered monitoring of glucose in diabetics is quite important and will save lives. The proposed self-powered biosensing microsystem will monitor sugar levels and it embodies two key new contributions: (1) The approach eliminates the need for a potentiostat circuit and an external power source or batteries, thus leading to dramatic improvements in both speed and energy efficiency. Enzyme biofuel cells based on three-dimensional nanowire anodes fused with an energy harvesting circuit and a capacitor will provide integrated devices that will sense input potential and step up the electric power to operate a light emitting diode. (2) The work is both innovative and transformational, since it will provide an autonomous, self-powered, low-power biosensing microsystem. The biosensing microsystem will generate a drive signal in real-time and periodically power an electrical device solely by generating and accumulating electrical power in the capacitor as a result of the catalysis of glucose oxidation.

Broad Impact: Both the research and educational objectives have a significant broader impact.
The research addresses a crucial problem in diabetes treatment - a self-powered biosensing microsystem for continuous monitoring of blood glucose. The combination of the two areas; nanowire enzyme-based biofuel cell and biosensing system; can usher in a new era in self-powered biosensor microsystems for glucose monitoring. Demonstration of a self-powered, stable, continuous, long-term biosensing microsystem for glucose could lead to improvement in the quality of life for people with diabetes. The educational component enriches and complements other programs at UMBC that are designed to increase minority and female participation in math and science. The exposure of these students to a real-world problem and its solution will enable them to better appreciate the contribution of scientific research.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The objective of self-powered biosensors is to develop a device suitable for harnessing the bioelectricity stored in blood metabolites (i.e., glucose) in the body to drive an electronic device (e.g., implantable glucose monitor). Various nanomaterials (free-standing nanowires, dense mesh network of multiwalled carbon nanotubes, nanoparticles, gas diffusion electrodes, etc.) and biorecognition elements (glucose oxidase, pyrroloquinoline quinone glucose dehydrogenase, laccase, and bilirubin oxidase) were explored in the design and development of the self-powered biosensing system. The two-dimensional array of nanowires exhibits large surface area that can improve enzyme loading (glucose oxidase and laccase). At physiologic glucose concentration (5 mM), an open-circuit potential of 389 mV and a maximum power density of 18.8 μW/cm2 at 0.17 V was obtained. Glucose dehydrogenase and laccase immobilized on mesh-dense network of multiwalled carbon nanotubes were investigated in order to optimize the power density achieved in the biofuel cell system. With this combination, we successfully developed a self-powered biosensing system through the integration of a single biofuel cell with a two-stage electrical power amplification circuit to generate usable electrical power while sensing glucose. This work demonstrates a stable self-powering glucose biosensing system constructed by combining a charge pump IC and a capacitor functioning as a transducer with a glucose biofuel cell. The glucose biofuel cell design when applied to various concentration of glucose analyte, demonstrated linearity up to 45 mM glucose. The glucose/O2 biofuel cell is capable of generating sufficient power from normal blood glucose concentration to power a light-emitting diode (LED) via a single glucose biofuel cell. This work constitutes the first stability study of self-powered biosensing system of this kind that is still able to deliver greater than 91% of its initial maximum power density after 63 days of operation.

In addition, we demonstrated a system using pyroloquinoline quinone glucose dehydrogenase-modified bioanode and bilirubin oxidase-modified biocathode capable of simultaneously sensing glucose and harnessing sufficient energy to power a digital device. The electrical parameters from a single biofuel cell were amplified to 1.4 V using a charge pump circuit consisting of a capacitive element that senses glucose. Furthermore, a steady output DC supply of 3.2 V was obtained by interfacing a step-up DC convertor circuit to the charge pump circuit. Such a system simultaneously senses glucose and harnesses energy in the presence of various glucose concentrations. We observed a 3.7-fold increase in sensor sensitivity when compared with previous self-powered glucose biosensors. The self-powered glucose biosensor that we report remains stable over 53 days of operation. In addition, we developed a flexible, nanocellulose-based, highly sensitive, glucose indicator that is capable of detecting glucose while powering an indicator (LED) simultaneously. We believe that this type of high-performance, self-powered glucose sensor system, combined with low-cost construction shows great potential for use in biotechnology applications relating to medical diagnosis and diabetes management.

Using the self-powered glucose biosensor encapsulated in medical grade silicone, we demonstrated its operation in human plasma glucose at clinically relevant human plasma glucose concentrations (2.78–11.11 mM) with high sensitivity. The glucose biofuel cell component achieved an open-circuit voltage of 392 mV and delivered a maximum power density of 0.462 mW·cm−2 at a cell voltage of 213 mV when operating 5 mM plasma glucose. The highest peak current density of 4.75 mA·cm−2 was obtained in 11.11 mM. This work further demonstrates that human plasma can be used as an energy source for biofuel cells and concurrently sense plasma glucose levels. These results lead to the conclusion that the self-powered glucose biosensor is a very attractive biosensor platform for monitoring glucose and are of particular significance for point-of-care diagnostics, where high sensitivities and detection limits below basal clinical levels are desired to enable early diagnostics. The present self-powered glucose biosensing system exhibits the potential to function as a stable, continuous glucose biosensor and has potential application in the development of a “closed-loop” insulin delivery system for simultaneously monitoring blood glucose levels and delivery of insulin. This novel self-powered glucose biosensing system shows a promising future for powering implantable devices and assessing patient health.

This research has resulted in the publication of one invited book chapter and over 35 peer-reviewed journal articles and conference proceedings. Our publications on enzymatic and non-enzymatic biofuel cells as well as self-powered glucose biosensing systems have been the source of numerous book and peer-reviewed articles. A total of 30 undergraduates, 7 M.S. students and 4 Ph.D. students have been mentored on this project. The grant enabled the creation of the Bioelectronics Summer Institute Program, which is a one-week residential and five-week non-residential academic program for rising 6th -10th graders and rising 11th - 12th graders from underrepresented in STEM who express a desire to pursue a career in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM). 

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2021
Modified by: Gymama Slaughter
